title: Fireworks display and fair scrapped after worker fell 40ft from roller coaster
text:

A fireworks display and funfair has been cancelled after a worker was seriously injured setting up a Winter Wonderland nearby.

The Lyme Valley Fireworks Display and Fun Fair in North Staffordshire will not go ahead tonight as planned after the 21-year-old man fell 40ft from the Crazy Mouse roller coaster just four miles down the road in Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent.

The man broke his pelvis and both his wrists in the fall on Saturday afternoon.

Witnesses claimed he had not been wearing a safety harness, and police seized harnesses as part of the investigation.

The Health and Safety Executive is also investigating.

Stoke-on-Trent Live reported that the Mayor's fireworks at Lyme Valley Parkway would not be going ahead tonight as planned.

Have you been affected by this story? Email webnews@mirror.co.uk

A statement online from Stanworths Fun Fairs said: "Due to unforeseen circumstances Lyme Valley Fireworks Display and Fun Fair is now cancelled.

"Sorry for any inconvenience caused."

Shocked witnesses told how the 21-year-old man "wobbled and fell" and was "shouting and screaming" after he landed with a sickening "thud" at the site in Stoke-on-Trent.

One of the witnesses said the worker "just stepped off and went straight down" when he plunged from the unfinished ride just after 3pm on Saturday.

Initially, there were fears that the man had suffered life-threatening injuries in the fall, which happened "for reasons unknown".

An air ambulance landed nearby, but the man went to hospital in a land ambulance, according to witnesses.

Tina Robinson, 52, was parked nearby while picking up her two daughters when she witnessed the incident.

She told StokeonTrentLive: "As I glanced up I saw a man on top of a roller coaster helping to put it up and suddenly he wobbled and fell.

"I ran round to see what had happened and there were two other workman with the man who was lying on the floor shouting and screaming. It was awful. It made me feel sick.

“I then heard the sirens. The police arrived within minutes and then the first responder arrived. As I left I saw more emergency services arriving. I just hope he is going to be OK.”

Frank Dale, 66, said: “I just came to have a look at them putting up the fairground and then that happened. It left me shocked.

“It was poor from a health and safety point of view. He was not wearing a harness. If he had been he would have still been on there.

“Let’s hope he is OK.”

Staffordshire police insisted yesterday that the accident at Winter Wonderland had nothing to do with the structure of the ride and said the building of the Winter Wonderland would continue.

It is set to open on November 14.
description: The event in north Staffordshire has been scrapped after a man broke his wrists and pelvis setting up Stoke-on-Trent's Winter Wonderland nearby
